title: 107_s1967
content: The Medicare Vision Rehabilitation Services Act of 2002, also known as the "Medicare Vision Rehabilitation Services Act," aims to improve outpatient vision services under Part B of the Social Security Act. This includes coverage for vision rehabilitation services as defined in the Act. Vision rehabilitation professionals will provide these services to eligible individuals. The term 'vision rehabilitation services' refers to rehabilitative services provided to individuals diagnosed with a vision impairment, as part of a care plan established by a qualified physician or occupational therapist, and delivered by qualified professionals in appropriate settings. The term 'qualified physician' refers to an ophthalmologist or a doctor of optometry who establishes and reviews the plan of care for vision rehabilitation services. The vision rehabilitation professional operates under the general supervision of the qualified physician, providing overall direction and control without the physician's presence required during service delivery. The term 'vision rehabilitation professional' includes orientation and mobility specialists, rehabilitation teachers, and low vision therapists. Orientation and mobility specialists are individuals licensed or certified by the state with a degree in orientation and mobility. The term 'rehabilitation teacher' refers to an individual licensed or certified by the state with a degree in rehabilitation teaching. They must meet specific criteria set by the Secretary and hold a baccalaureate or higher degree. A low vision therapist is an individual who holds a baccalaureate or higher degree with a concentration in rehabilitation teaching or a health field, has completed 350 hours of clinical practicum, passed a national examination, and meets criteria set by the Secretary. To become a licensed low vision therapist, one must hold a relevant degree, complete 350 hours of clinical practicum, pass a national examination, and meet criteria set by the Secretary. The term 'vision impairment' refers to significant vision loss that cannot be corrected by conventional means, such as refractive correction or surgery, and is characterized by specific visual limitations. The Secretary may determine appropriate diagnoses, indications, or manifestations. Amendments are made to the Physician fee schedule and the hospital outpatient department prospective payment system under Part B of the Social Security Act. Clarification of billing requirements is also addressed. Amendments are made to the billing requirements for vision rehabilitation services under the Social Security Act, specifying payment to qualified physicians or facilities providing such services. Amendments to billing requirements for vision rehabilitation services under the Social Security Act include specifying payment to qualified physicians or facilities providing services under a contractual arrangement. Vision rehabilitation services must be required due to individual need and be part of an individualized written plan of care. Amendments to billing requirements for vision rehabilitation services under the Social Security Act specify payment to qualified physicians or facilities providing services under a contractual arrangement. Services must be part of an individualized plan of care established by a qualified physician, occupational therapist, or vision rehabilitation professional, periodically reviewed by the physician, and provided while under their care. The provision of vision rehabilitation services under Medicare shall not impact the Rehabilitation Act of 1973. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will publish an interim rule within 180 days of the enactment of this section to implement its provisions. The rule will be effective immediately but subject to change after a public comment period of at least 60 days. The Secretary will consult with relevant organizations in developing the rule. Certification of Vision Rehabilitation and Education Professionals will be determined by the Secretary in consultation with various professional and consumer organizations as part of regulations to implement this Act.
